issues.description: The problem statement's UML for Stock declares a method named emptyStock(): void, and the reference solution implements emptyStock(). However, the template repository's Stock class provides a method named clearInventory() instead of emptyStock(). This name/signature mismatch between template and problem/solution is structural: students following the template will not find emptyStock() as described in the specification and may be confused which method to implement or call (and automated tests or the reference solution may expect emptyStock()).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Either rename the template's clearInventory() to emptyStock() (or add an emptyStock() method that delegates to clearInventory()), or update the problem statement/UML and the solution to use clearInventory() instead. Preferably align the template to the UML by adding public void emptyStock() { this.clearInventory(); } or renaming clearInventory to emptyStock().

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) refer to a Stock method named emptyStock(), but the template repository provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This is a naming mismatch for the same conceptual operation (clearing the stock) and can confuse students: they may look for emptyStock() as specified in the exercise but only find clearInventory() in the starter code, or they may implement an emptyStock method unaware that the template already has the functionality under a different name.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across artifacts. Prefer renaming the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock() to match the problem statement and solution. Alternatively, add an emptyStock() wrapper in the template that delegates to clearInventory(), and update any exercise text to consistently use the chosen name.
